name: Muslim Community Network
mission: We are dedicated to using civic education and leadership development to shape the public narrative about what it means to be Muslim in America.

geographicCoverage: New York City (New York, United States)
Brooklyn (Kings County, New York, United States)

theoryOfChange: Equipping community leaders and service providers with cultural competency and safety tools leads to safer, stronger, and more civically engaged communities.
zakatClaimEvidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://mcnny.org/donate (Source: https://mcnny.org/donate)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Good donor alignment with manageable risk. Evidence quality is solid but still evolving in places.

components.evidence: Explicit zakat program (+4); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Islamic identity (+1); Humanitarian service (+2)
components.improvement_suggestion: Clarify zakat allocation policy and eligible use categories for donors.
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

alignment.rationale: Alignment 28/50: MEDIUM Muslim donor fit, religious cultural cause area

components.evidence: No beneficiary data available for cost-per-beneficiary scoring; moderate program ratio (≥65%)
components.improvement_suggestion: Publish beneficiary counts consistently so cost-effectiveness can be assessed.
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes over at least 3 years.
components.name: Evidence & Outcomes

components.improvement_suggestion: Document a clear theory of change with an explicit causal pathway.
components.name: Theory of Change

score_details.score_summary: MCN shows strong impact and good alignment, with zakat compliance. Evidence score may reflect limited reporting capacity, not program weakness.

zakat.claim_evidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://mcnny.org/donate (Source: https://mcnny.org/donate)

all_citations.claim: MCN reported total revenue of $768,698 and focuses on civic education and leadership programs.
The organization is zakat-eligible and provides information on zakat policy and asnaf categories.
MCN provides multiple donation options and giving methods for supporters.
MCN holds a 98.0/100 score with a program expense ratio of 72.9% and 8.2 months of working capital.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: MCN earns a GMG score of 64/100, reflecting exceptional financial health and transparency balanced by its focus on long-term capacity building rather than immediate humanitarian relief.
areas_for_improvement: Limited direct cost-per-beneficiary data available for impact assessment
Moderate alignment for donors seeking high-urgency humanitarian relief versus long-term civic capacity building

dimension_explanations.alignment: The organization offers a medium donor fit for those focused on civic identity, maintaining a total revenue of $768,698 to support its mission [1]. Its status as zakat-eligible aligns with the needs of Muslim donors looking to support community-based asnaf categories [2].
dimension_explanations.impact: MCN demonstrates high financial health with a program expense ratio of 72.9% and 8.2 months of working capital [1][4]. While its capacity-building model makes direct cost-per-beneficiary metrics less applicable, its high Charity Navigator score of 98.0/100 indicates strong organizational effectiveness [4].

baseline_narrative.headline: MCN empowers the American Muslim community through civic education and leadership development to reshape public narratives and foster social change.
strengths: High financial accountability with a Charity Navigator score of 98.0/100
Strong fundraising efficiency, spending only $0.05 to raise every $1
Zakat-eligible status supported by clear organizational policies
baseline_narrative.summary: MCN is a non-profit organization dedicated to shaping the public narrative of Muslims in America through youth leadership, community education, and civic engagement programs [1]. The organization is recognized as zakat-eligible, allowing donors to fulfill their religious obligations through various giving methods [2][3].

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: MCN earns a GMG score of 64/100, reflecting exceptional financial health and transparency balanced by its focus on long-term capacity building rather than immediate humanitarian relief.

areas_for_improvement.context: There is currently no beneficiary data available for cost-per-beneficiary scoring, limiting the ability to assess direct cost-effectiveness.
The organization currently meets <cite id="4">0/20 BBB Wise Giving Alliance standards</cite>, presenting an opportunity to strengthen governance documentation.

bbb_assessment.summary: Currently meets 0 of the 20 BBB Wise Giving Alliance Standards for Charity Accountability.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization maintains a Platinum Seal of Transparency from Candid and tracks 3 outcome metrics, indicating a commitment to improving measurement.
risk_factors: No beneficiary data available for cost-per-beneficiary scoring
Meets 0/20 BBB Wise Giving Alliance standards
case_against.summary: The primary limitation is the lack of direct cost-per-beneficiary data and the niche focus on domestic civic engagement, which may not align with donors seeking immediate humanitarian relief.

confidence.notes: Strong financial data availability, but limited impact measurement data.

alignment.explanation: MCN offers a medium Muslim donor fit, operating in the religious cultural cause area with <cite id="2">zakat-eligible</cite> programs.
alignment.improvement: Clarify zakat allocation policy and eligible use categories for donors.

credibility.explanation: Donors can trust MCN due to its <cite id="4">98/100 overall score from Charity Navigator</cite> and Platinum Seal of Transparency from Candid.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility further, the charity could complete BBB Wise Giving Alliance accreditation.

impact.explanation: Operations show an excellent <cite id="1">72.9% program expense ratio</cite> and strong financial resilience with <cite id="4">8.2 months of working capital</cite>.
impact.improvement: Publish beneficiary counts consistently so cost-effectiveness can be assessed.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Some outcome tracking through Candid

rich_narrative.headline: MCN empowers the American Muslim community through civic education and leadership development to reshape public narratives and foster social change.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to invest in long-term civic capacity building and leadership development for American Muslims.
donor_motivations: Value domestic community empowerment and narrative change
Want to support highly efficient organizations with low fundraising costs
Seek to fulfill zakat obligations through local capacity building
giving_considerations: Impact is long-term and systemic rather than immediate relief
Programs are geographically concentrated in the New York area
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking immediate international humanitarian relief or those who require rigorous academic evidence of cost-per-life-saved.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C indicates the organization tracks some outcome metrics (3 metrics via Candid) but lacks rigorous external evaluations or cost-per-beneficiary data.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: MCN empowers the American Muslim community through civic education and leadership development to reshape public narratives.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence helps ensure donations create real impact and allows donors to compare cost-effectiveness across different interventions.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: With $768,698 in revenue and a 10.9% CAGR, the organization is growing steadily and has capacity to expand its local programs.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by its specific focus on the New York City area and high <cite id="1">72.9% program expense ratio</cite>.
peer_comparison.peer_group: Domestic Muslim civic and community development organizations

similar_organizations.differentiator: Focuses on Chicago area with broader social services
similar_organizations.name: Inner-City Muslim Action Network

strengths.detail: The organization directs <cite id="1">72.9% of its budget to program expenses</cite> and spends just <cite id="1">$0.05 to raise every $1</cite>, indicating highly efficient operations.
MCN has earned a <cite id="4">98/100 overall score from Charity Navigator</cite>, reflecting excellent accountability and financial health.
The organization is <cite id="2">zakat-eligible</cite>, providing a unique opportunity for donors to support American Muslim civic engagement and leadership development.

strengths_deep_dive: MCN demonstrates robust financial health and operational efficiency. With <cite id="1">$768,698 in total revenue</cite> for 2023, the organization has maintained a <cite id="1">10.9% 3-year revenue CAGR</cite>. Their commitment to maximizing impact is evident in their <cite id="1">72.9% program expense ratio</cite> and highly efficient fundraising, costing only <cite id="1">$0.05 to raise every $1</cite>. This financial stewardship is independently verified by a <cite id="4">98/100 overall score from Charity Navigator</cite>.
rich_narrative.summary: Muslim Community Network (MCN) is a non-profit organization dedicated to shaping the public narrative of Muslims in America through youth leadership, community education, and civic engagement programs. In 2023, the organization reported <cite id="1">$768,698 in total revenue</cite>, demonstrating a steady growth trajectory with a <cite id="1">10.9% 3-year revenue CAGR</cite>. MCN operates with exceptional financial efficiency, directing <cite id="1">72.9% of its budget to program expenses</cite> while spending only <cite id="1">$0.05 to raise every $1</cite>. The organization maintains strong independent validation, including a <cite id="4">98/100 overall score from Charity Navigator</cite> and a Platinum Seal of Transparency from Candid. Furthermore, MCN is <cite id="2">zakat-eligible</cite>, allowing donors to fulfill their religious obligations while supporting domestic civic capacity building.
